name: Hero of the Kingdom
description: You were living a calm life on your farm with your father. Those times are gone. Flames have turned your house into ashes. Your father is missing. A darkness is falling over the whole country and you are setting off on a dangerous journey. This is going to be the greatest adventure of your life.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP, Vista, 7, 8, 10 Processor: 1.0 GHz Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: 128 MB, DirectX 9.0 DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 300 MB available space Additional Notes: Mouse or touch control

reviews.review_text: I just finished Hero of the Kingdom (2.5 hours, give or take). It's a very unique game. Basically you're presented a top-down isometric screen that looks a little bit like Age of Empires 2 or HoMM3 or something. You click through text prompts on the screen in a sort of combination text adventure and hidden object game. You become a hero of your kingdom by moving through screens and helping people out. Maybe someone lost their son, so you hidden object find him. Nothing is difficult, it'll just be like you see a patch of mushrooms, and you click it so you get mushrooms added to your inventory. Or you are on your boat and click a barrel underwater to salvage it. So not really hidden object, more like click-to-acquire. Maybe a farmer needs someone to go to town to sell his flour, so you get flour, click to switch screens to the town, and sell the flour to a merchant. Your inventory has dozens of different types of commodities that you manage, flowers, eggs, swords, handymen, antlers, pearls, etc. Across the world various merchants buy and sell various commodities. There's no actual difficulty in that it seems like it's impossible to make a bad transaction. If you just keep buying and selling stuff and foraging and fishing and hunting you'll eventually get enough of what you need or enough money to buy what you need. I really can't compare it to any other game I've ever played. I had a fun time playing through it. I guess I wasn't really playing. Just kind of clicking everywhere.  I also laughed every time I'd go into some big climactic battle and my guy would be like 'We scored a crushing victory over the Dark Goblins. Oh and all of my soldiers died. We will miss them.' and then -10 soldiers in my inventory. Hahaha. Made them feel very disposable.  One flaw: The game autosaves and when you beat the game it erases your saves, meaning that if you want to get all the achievements you should do so BEFORE fighting the last boss (the last boss is clearly marked and identified).

There's full of positive reviews about Hero of the Kindom and mine won't be different..  Personal Rating: Fun and relaxing, i enjoyed it so much. Classic Rating: ★★★★☆  This short game is like a point&click adventure with hidden objects: its simplicity, clever logic, beautiful setting and storyline really impressed me. I can't find anything bad about it, it's very rewarding for the loot you can find and achievemens are not too hard to get, even if i finished the game before getting them all - but i really do not mind it.  I bought this one on a bundle but i would recommend you to buy it even at full price, because it's really worth the money.

Quaint like an elderly lady's bungalow filled with many past adventures and expeditions, the attractively detailed land in  Hero of the Kingdom  possesses the old-fashioned quest-orientated method of play that I have yearned for through many wishful Steam purchases but had yet to truly discover until now.   Hero of the Kingdom  ranks highly in my gaming library as one of the most satisfyingly rewarding games I have played on Steam to date. It is most certainly one of the top 3 which I eagerly gave myself an auspicious pat on the back for buying. At $1.49 (75% off) it is money well spent. Completion only took me two days totalling 8 hours or so (didn't bother to quit game when taking dog for a walk). The game play is therapeutic and healing as even with a generic storyline, the long but seldom arduous line of quests are gratifyingly addictive.  If you enjoy RPGs as I do and rarely skip side quests as it is half the fun , then I highly recommend this title.   The controls are as easy as can be and I can't honestly admit this is a strategy game as it does not give the player a chance at failure as you will see if you play it. It isn't a game to test your gaming skills but a chance to relax from more demanding games. Out of games you can use to relax and enjoy like you used to enjoy games as a child, it never feels like a waste of time or is uncomfortable to play in terms of time or effort of lack thereof.    Hero of the Kingdom is my idea of a perfect holiday.

This is a point & click games with strategic resource management & progressive hidden object content.  The story begins with that that the maincharakter looses his home & goes to an adventure to beat an evil mage.  +good story +calm game +easy archivements +no frustrating +uncomplicated control +looks like an rpg +clear game +is addicting  Big - :too short  9.95/10  Buy it,if you like point & click games.

A decent casual rpg-like game . Its short, casual , fun for wasting your time, actually it is better than that, and I also had fun doing 100% achievement completion. I started playing it to waste my time but it turned out to be more fun than expected. Just don't expect a great , story or complex mechanics and you're good to go.

Huh. I never would've thought a game like this would've interested me long enough to fully complete it. Part hidden-object, part memory game, Hero of the Kingdom is a relaxing click through fantasy. There are a few tedious moments, but the interface makes it easy to accomplish the harder tasks, as long as you can recall where the stuff you need is, and what you need to have to get it. 5 out of 5 hidden mushrooms

Relaxing Point & Click Adventure. I'm generally not into this kind of games, but i really liked it. The story is nice, the quests are diversified, and it is fun to hunt down all the achievements. After finishing the game, you really fell like the hero of the kingdom!

Sort of an adventure, but not really ---- it's different and unique. You have to leave the peace of your farm to find your father who seems to be in the hands of bandits. As you go, there are a ton of simple tasks to perform (find this, build that, etc.) for the various people you meet along the way. You have to keep up with your supplies, your energy, and your list of all the tasks. While the approach is very relaxed, there is some strategy involved so you have to stay alert and not waste the resources you have on a task that won't push the game forward. Somewhat like a TM game, but involves resources.  The mechanics are flawless, and the artwork is great.  It is a simple and clever game that moves a bit slowly for me, but I think it's worth a look. Might be just what you're looking for.   So I recommend giving the demo a go, at least.

Although it feels like a game originally designed for the mobile platform, Hero of the Kingdom is a treat nevertheless. The story is nothing special: your home is destroyed, your father is missing, and you must track him down. Your adventure quickly becomes larger in scale, and the eventual revelations are interesting, fitting, and satisfying. The gameplay is quickly accessible, but it takes a good deal of planning and resource management to get the tools, soldiers, medicines, and weapons you'll need to overcome your many foes. There are a variety of secrets to find in the environments, so that each new map is a treasure hunt for necessary materials and wildlife.   Hero of the Kingdom is a brief game and can be completed at around 5 hours. Achievements come regularly and keep you motivated. While the art style is simple, I found it charming and appropriate for this sort of adventure. I easily recommend this game for my friends who enjoy games which are a little different yet delightful.

7/10 Point and click adventure meets Where's Waldo mat gathering and hunting. Oddly addictive, don't know why. Completed game with all achievements in 4 hrs. Buy on sale for no more than a couple of bucks. I did enjoy it. No replay value.

This game really surprised me out of the blue , has a great story , rpg mechanics , tons of pixel hunting . For those looking to explore into casual , simple adventure/rpg games this one will surely get you into this.  Pros :-  Great story, progresses nicely Easy game mechanics , allows you to explore a bit  Cons :-  Achievement hunters will face epic pixel hunting challenges to get everything in the game.

Click here, click there. Linear story. This game is FAR OVERRATED. BUYER BEWARE, please know that you are buying a linear, economic clicking game without any RPG elements. This is like an interactive childrens book, no disrespect to the devs.

This was a very enjoyable game. I don't think it has any replay value since the sotry is linear, but it was a welcomed change of pace. it is basically a living story with a seek and find mini game for the challenges.

I'm a cynical sort when it comes to games. There are so many of them on Steam, and with debacles like NMS, it's easy to become a bit jaded. I typically avoid most hidden object games to boot, so when I fired up Hero of the Kingdom I expected something pretty boring and tedious. I'm happy to say that I was wrong - and what I found recaptured some old memories for me.  Remember when you were a kid, discovering games for the first time, and letting your imagination whisk you away? I'm nearly thirty now, and that feeling is too rare these days. Hero of the Kingdom didn't blow me away, but it did help me remember that sometimes games can be like a cosy blanket that you settle into at the end of the day. A hot mug of tea and a crackling fire in winter - that's what this game is. The simple, rustic fantasy setting and verdant aesthetic, the gentle score and straightforward-yet-rewarding gameplay all combine very well to create a surprisingly immersive experience. The whole is much greater than the sum, I feel.  You start out with a pretty typical fantasy trope via your farm being burned to ashes by bandits, and your father going missing. From there, you embark on an adventure to capture all the krayfish and mercilessly steal eggs from nests. I mean, erm, 'helping fellow villagers'. These tasks range in importance...some are incredibly menial, some revolve around the livelihood of an NPC, and others up the stakes towards the prevention of an apocalypse. It's all quite homely, although the game doesn't shy away from generic soldiers getting killed. Essentially, the gameplay revolves around resource management in a point & click environment - collect materials, trade them, sell them for cash, and so forth. You're fairly well railroaded at first, although at around the halfway point you can elect to ditch the sidequests in favour of just buying everything, if you're happy to buy/sell accordingly and get an endless profit going.  I was sceptical, but Hero of the Kingdom won me over from the outset. I beat the game in six hours, and I was thoroughly impressed. Well worth the cash when it's on sale, if only for being able to indulge your inner child for a few hours. I didn't even find all the collectables, but I don't mind that - it just gives me an excuse to come back and play it all again in a few months time...

Real cool RPG/Hidden Object/Narrative game. Its very easy to get into, I'm a pretty big gamer but the average person who likes fantasy stories will like it. Love the backgrounds, music/sfx is good, story is great. Enjoy!

Excellent little adventure game. Very casual. Linear story, with lots of click on the screen to do X. If you are looking for high strategy, action or rpging, then this is not it. However if you want a fun game to play with a non-gaming spouse or child, or you want to kill an afternoon without a lot of brainpower required, then this is very fun.

This is a fun little game if you just want to waste some time, or if you like hidden object and resource management games. It's got nice graphics for a small game, a decent storyline, and is playable for about 4-6 hours. It doesn't really have replayability though. If you go for all of the achievemnts, then trying to get the last eggs, crates, and mushrooms can be a bit annoying. I was able to get this on sale for $0.59, so it was very much worth my money, but I $6 is a bit much for it. Maybe more like $2 or $3. I think that it is a cute, relaxing game that I reccommmend, along with its sequel.
Nice little adventure. Slow and relaxing.

*Click* *Click* *Click* *Click* *Click* Casual game with a rather pale story and some 'search those 5 pixels in a picture'-moments. Good game for easy achievments, bad game if you pay more than 2 bucks.   Hero of the Kingdom is a point and click adventure mixed with a resource manager. You travel through different overview screens, visiting villages, mountains, forests and so on. On your way, you pick up items either by clicking (said 'Search those 5 pixels'-moments) or by buying/trading/questing at NPCs. The more you progress, the more resources you have. For example you need Energy to fight (a boar or wolf costs X energy), which you replenish by sleeping. You can sleep when you pay gold at inns or in the wild, if you have enough food on you (different camping sites ask for different kinds of food). You can also carry items, which hold longer (Weapons and tools, though they might break sometimes) Sadly, the system is kinda broken after a while for those, who notice how to milk endless gold out of the resource cycle. Maybe a patch would help here?  The artwork is pretty good, I expect the designer to give us a full course of his abilities in the future. Everything looks very detailed and alive and every screen carries a different kind of atmosphere with it The background music is nothing outstanding, but it doesnt kill the atmosphere either. 'Generic' comes to my mind here.  Still, seeing as this is an endless orgy of clicking and searching I can not recommend it at its current price of 6 Euro. Maybe some mini-games and riddles would have helped to add simply MORE CONTENT to this game. In the end I just played it to gather all achievments, having absolutely no interest for an ending (and there is only one. Why not make different endings, depending on how you choose to solve quests and stuff? A simple BAD Ending would even give more depth...)

Like one giant fetch quest but with only the rewards. Lots of fun. Half hidden object, half money management, half so-so story. It's well worth it on sale and a few hours of your time. What? That's 3 halves? Don't talk to me like that! I'm the HERO!

A fast paced FPS RTS action simulation RPG. . . Hell no! This game is just simply good.  Let's call the style 'resource adventure' with clicking and looting. You can do things and advance in the story only if you have enough resources gathered. Pretty charmy at first but too much fight later but an overall relaxing game (maybe cos i played it after 'Afterfall Insanity' that's why :P ). A real pearl even to adventure-dumbs like me.

Fun waste of time. Waste a couple of hours incessantly clicking objects and you'll win no matter what. Pro tip: Click everything, even in that one spot where you think it will actually hurt your chances of getting a perfect score.   For fans of Where's Waldo. Ideal audience: 7-10 year olds.  negs: Zero role playing. A first person narrative is not role playing.   $7 is a rip off for something that you could find more content in a $1 phone app, but gamers spend more on worse so who cares.

100% completion in roughly 6 hours.....but i had a blast playing this clicker rpg. vague storyline, assorted quests and side quests with a little hidden object fun to it. i got it cheap, i suggest you do the same.

A little gem.   Simple and direct yet with a distinctive charm. I thoroughly recommend it if only to witness the work of love that is openly apparent in the way the design melds together. Looking forward to the sequel.

Very addictive game, even if all you have to do is click. The story and events are very entertaining so I wish it was even longer.  I finished the game in one sitting (3.8 hours) and got all the trophy available.   Tip for anyone who want to start playing. Collect EVERYTHING xD
No real game. Just keeps you busy with klicking tasks and rewards you with achievements. Collect herbs until the Dark Lord is defeated!
this game is boring all you have to do is find item to complete the quest and find hidden item  this game is not even worth the price

At first glance this probably doesn't look like very much. It might be confusing as to what type of game it is.  Despite being tagged by many as an RPG, this is definitely an adventure game. It isn't very dialogue heavy but the storyline is more than sufficient, and although it is essentially linear, it cleverly gives the illusion of not being so. It is longer than you might expect, and tracks the story of a young boy on his journey to save his father. It's fairly generic, but the style of the game is rather unique, so this is easily forgiven.  Be careful- you might read elsewhere online that you can get achievements after you complete the game by continuing. This isn't true. I found this out the hard way and will have to get the rest when I play it again someday. I can't judge the developer for this, though.
★★★★★★★★☆☆ 8/10 nice but short (i finish it in 5.4h)

This amazing game was definately worth it's price!  Hero of the Kingdom is point'n'click fabular game. You live on a small farm away from the civilization - suddenly your father was kidnapped by bandits. You have to rescue him, and... You'll see by your own! :)  Story was quite good. This game's story is more for a children than an adult, but i enjoyed it. It's really simple. like in classical point'n'click you have to click on terrain to find hidden treasures, or get resources. There are also some interesting side quests with ghosts and more. There are 3 skills - Alchemy, Hunting and Fishing, and nothing more - that's not RPG game with all those stats. What's more, you can buy and sell some stuff, and do some simple side quests. game is for 2-4 hours.   The biggest con was unsophisticated story - and that's all. As i said on the start, game was worth it's price and I reccomend it to every point'n'click and medieval fan!

Fun, relaxing game. Definitely no brain-drain here. Maybe a slight bit of tedium if you want to stockpile the money and tools. For instance, I buy grain, go down 2 maps to have it ground then back up to turn it into bread then down four maps to sell them to the farmer's wife.   But that's just the OCD'er in me. Probably unnecessary since there's plenty of things to gather that you can sell. I was just always afraid I'd sell off things that might be needed in one of the fetch quests later.  That's pretty much the game; Story-driven RPG element fetch quests and hidden objects. If you don't like those two gameplay elements then pass on this. If you're okay with them then this is a definite buy at this price, because you will be kept busy and entertained.  Good music, nice scenery, nice story, laid-back gameplay. The perfect relaxing game to sit down with either with your morning coffee, or to unwind after a long day at work or school.
This game is Where's Waldo, forest edition, RPG-lite. Very relaxing point and click find/buy/sell things to complete quests to become the Hero of the Kingdom.

6.5/10 - RPG Adventure Mixes With Photo Hunt!  A fun RPG game that takes you on an epic journey. Your father leaves you in charge of the farm and someone burns it down while you are away. The worst part, now your father is missing. Gameplay mixes in some strategy, collecting and picture hunt elements. You can 100% this campaign in under 3 hours!  I constantly see this game on sale for $1, so I would look for it at that price point. This game is pretty fun though and worth more than that.     Accidently Reviewed

Hero of the Kingdom is a wonderful little light RPG disguised as a Hidden Object style game. While undeniably linear, the world is beautifully serene and I actually found myself just leaving the game running as a desktop. The entire adventure takes place from a satellite style view and on each screen of the world there are different activities, shops and quests to do. In addition to the obvious activity bubbles, there are also unmarked collectibles hidden throughout the world. These items for the most part are just another source of income but some also are part of crafting recipes. Everything is as simple as point and click, but rather than being boring it helps to keep the game from overstaying its welcome. The art and sound design is nearly flawless, with my only gripe being a strange soundtrack switch that happens occasionally when navigating through sections of the world and anything faster than a leisurely stroll. The “campaign” in its entirety will only set you back a few hours, but I think it is well worth it for how much detail and care went into this game.

I voted this game in greenlight ,and as soon as I seen it on sale I had to buy it. It is such an nice little point and click game and i have enjoyed playing it. I had to play through twice though, to get all my acheviments,and thoroughly enjoyed completing it.What would be really nice,is if this developer could extend this game with extra add on's maybe,to make the game much longer as I would most definetly go back, and play it again with more acheviements.what can I say but this is a nice little game,i think. :)

A very casual resource management game. Picked this up in a bundle and decided to install and play based on the art and was completely surprised by it. I thought after clearing the initial area the tutorial-esque prompts would lessen, but no, not really, it's basically how the game works.  Most of the game is based on needing x amount of item a,b,c to accomplish z. This sounds boring and repetitive, but for some reason, I really enjoyed it. Maybe it was the art direction or how low-taxing it is, but I played this for like a half and hour on my first start-up and then spent the next day waiting to get home to play it again. It's a short game and I think I finished it over the next two days. There was something chill and captivating about this game and I really enjoyed despite it being very simple in design and execution. The English translation can also be awfully stiff at times.  I think most people would find this game boring, but I definitely enjoyed this and will probably pick the sequel that is currently in the works when it comes out. Maybe the casual pastoral resource management genre is my thing.

One great little game! Casual mix of point & click with HOPA, interesting (yet cliché story), charming (and nostalgic) graphics, relaxing music... It is also very easy and short game, and this game really deserves to be played.

This game is an uninspired click grind. The idea and execution would be forgiveable, even diverting (when somewhat desperate), but the game requires you to grind for gold, and even the most efficient methods of getting gold take hundreds upon hundreds of clicks to reach the required amount. Furthermore, the collectables that you're supposed to gather on the side (for achievements or gold) are tiny-little-miniscule splotches that you'll strain your eyes to find. After having beaten the entire game, I can say that it is approximately as bad as it looked like it would be, with some additional lost points for grinding, and some very minor recovery of points if you like the search and find style of game.

Would be a great game if we were still in the 90s Looks like a HD remaster of some game from that time. Repetitive music, static graphics (seriously, there aren`t even battle animations or whatever) and long, static paragraphs of text. Reminds me a lot of Tibia, the MMORPG  BUT  I suppose its nostalgic, right? I mean, the graphics can throw you off quite a bit in the beginning and OH SO MUCH RAILROADING, but its a classic solo rpg, in the end. With half-♥♥♥♥♥ graphics and storytelling to boot. (seriously the story branches off in a million directions that end up being just sidequests. Its like Skyrim except its all 'gather me twenti fishe :) ')   Its not absolute trash, I still play it. And it WAS like $0,99 anyways so I guess its not retchable Bad. but not unplayable. 4/10
Fun little game, which is quite addictive. The good thing is that you can play through it in 2-3 hours. It is not fighting or RPG, but rather trading and finding items on the screen.

I'm always on the lookout for fun and addicting games and this is definitely one of them.  It's fast, easy and not too linear. The plot, which 'yes' has been done before, feels surprisingly fresh. Also 'hidden object' aspect of the game has been implemented very well. Eggs, mushrooms and chests hunt is very satisfying.  So far so good.

Looking at the reviews, I decided to give this game a try as I was looking for a new RPG to try. Unfortunately, this isn't really much of an RPG. It's more of a point and click adventure. There's a bit of reading, a bit of clicking, and mostly just monotiny.
The game is nice but has a lot of startup problems and I can't seem to make it work with AMD graphic card, as a few other people in the Steam Community forums

Fun, simple but interesting story :).  Relaxing playthrough, but still relatively engaging storyline and interesting characters. Enjoyable minor strategy/trading elements. 5 hours completion time, all achievements included.  Overall rating: 6/10
Nice casual game. Interface could be better and faster though... I hope the second part plays quicker.

This game is an absolute abortion. Aside from it being the most generic storyline in the history of games, the gameplay itself holds your hand for everything. It is far from enjoyable, and even a 5 year old would be bored after about 5 minutes. Save your money.
Cannot even run the game for longer than 1 minute without getting Unhandled Exceptions.

This is one serious time-sink in veins of every Facebook game ever. You're shown static images where you get to click stuff to get more stuff to divide into other stuff. And clickety-effing-clickety I went. Something like 100 minutes of pure clicking. Damn. I clicked a wood pile and got wood. I clicked a broken fence and the wood was gone. I couldn't see 'me' there so I believe the player is some sort of all mighty God that only needs to click to get ♥♥♥♥ done. World was just different areas for me since gods move with golden arrows from the edge of areas. I killed animals for their meat and then rested using that meat. When I clicked some people hey asked for help and I freaking delivered! Apples for ♥♥♥♥♥es? Sure, done. Flowers for the old hag? Consider it done. Arrows for Legolas, already there. Flour needed? Please. I found boxes under the water since apparently trashing is a real thing in fantasy worlds. Click. Click click.
This may just be alot of clicking, but I enjoyed it, lots of hidden objects and resource gathering.  Took 4 hours to complete 100%.

This is one of those casual games that has just enough complexity to keep a child of eight years entertained. It's pretty much a clickfest with a 'I'm a farmboy and I must save my dad!' story. No real 'combat' or 'crafting', just 'Make sure you have enough things to do the thing before you try the thing'. There's a little bit of 'hidden object' gameplay thrown in as well, and as small as these objects are, they still pop out well enough if you know what you're looking for.  It's short, it's sweet, it's not-perfectly translated from Slovak. Buy it if you have kids, or even for yourself if you're suffering from just the teensiest bit of MMORPG ennui.
Gread game. You should pay up to $25 for this game.
nice game 8/10 +smooth +easy to play +nice story +good gameplay +unique  -short story
One of the best indie game I have ever played, well worth every penny spent.

Hero of the Kingdom is a point-and-click role-playing game. It's more casual and story-driven than the average role-playing game. It is well-written and comes together naturally. After this game you could buy the sequel that's similar but has a different character and storyline.  Since the game is more casual, you have plenty of time to make decisions. I recommend it for people looking for a relaxing, story-driven role-playing game or someone that wants to try something different in the role-playing genre.
Too much clicking for my tastes.
great game! thanks on developers
I thoroughly enjoyed this little game. Recommended as a good way to fill in time, well written and simple, but with charm.

This was fun. Fundamentally, a fun little thing to play. It's like a point and click adventure with the puzzles swapped out with resource managment and object hunting. It is not a challenging game but it is definitely entertaining.
This is very awesome game with wonderfull story (although in some moments it is kind of predictable). Simple yet cute graphics. Really liked it. This game is made for relaxing play.

Very much enjoyed this game, Hero of the Kingdom was fantastic. Great story with entertaining game play. It ended before I was ready for it to... in other words, I want more! Great stuff! Give this one a try!

$2 for a few hours of entertainment well spent. I would have spent the money again in a second.  This game is not intended for someone looking for a heavy challenge. I enjoy looking for the hidden treasures and items to collect your achievements. The game also has a fun storyline to follow. Not at any point do you have to worry about dying its more remembering where to get certain items to complete miniquests.   I love how some call themselves hardcore gamers and won't play a game like this. In my opinion if you are hardcore you will play any game as long as it is fun. If you only play one style of game then that only means you have no mind to go outside of the trends. I love FPS, Survival Horror, Puzzle, Hidden Object, and many other styles. This was well worth the money spent for a good fun casual time. Great job devs, I want more! =D
Casual old-school RPG with decent execution. Very short campaign.

This is like an RPG, but without combat or any real failure states. It's more a point-and-click adventure/hidden object game than anything else, I suppose. Kind of simple and not particularly long but it's surprisingly engaging. Could be the inherent lack of challenge involved. There's nothing to make you want to stop playigng, so you keep on playing. Probably a decent game to get from a bundle but not one I'd recommend at full price. Also, pixel hunting can be kind of a chore.

Story was very basic, but the number of quests and tasks to complete never had a dull moment. There was always something to do - be it gathering ingredients to craft products to sell, or to hand in a quest. A great indie game and there is too much finding stuff and clicking. My hand hurts. 8/10 for capturing my attention from beginning to end!  I took 3 hours to complete it. You could probably do it in less.

This game surprised me. It was extremely relaxing. This is one of those games where you can lay in bed and play with just the mouse. Sure it's a point and click story bookish game, but combined with the cute but immersive graphics, sound effects, music, and dialogue, it successfully pulls the player into its world. Sure the plot was quite predictable but it was quite satisfying as a result. The art was beautifully done, emulating more classical 8-16 bit graphics. I beat the game in two days, however on the second day I couldn't wait to finish school to rush home and continue the story, I just couldn't put this title down until it was finished. It also had quite a unique battle system, if you can call it that... For what this game is, 9/10 from me.  Cons: -No replay-ability. -The end game was a tiny bit monotonous but it's a small inconvenience. -Easter egg hunting tiny objects for side-quests is annoying. -Lots of back tracking... and memorization...

Recommended... If you like this kind of game. So what exactly is it? I'd describe it as a short, linear story driven resource collection game with a bit of hidden object along the way. Pretty much a top down point and click adventure.  Despite the looks, it is definitely not: A city building game A strategy game An RPG (in the skyrim/mass effecty sense of the word)  The story is cliched as can be, the artwork fairly pleasant, the difficulty not to challenging. It's a very laid back game, that is enjoyable because you feel like you're constantly progressing, and everything fits together tightly. The worst part of it was a mid-game lack of money, but I had missed that hunting trophies and fish are mainly for selling (and only occasionally for quests).   I completed everything (absolutely) in 4 hours, so this is only a short diversion. If you want a short point and click adventure from a different perspective, this is a fair option.

Ok. I wanted something nice and relaxing. Boy did I get it. This game is a gem. It won't take you that long to beat. But trust me it is worth buying especially at so little a cost. I played it during a lazy sunday and it definately brightened my mood. It is a very casual game which is a nice change. Also I would recomend either decent eyesite or a large screen. I had trouble spotting the odd mushroom and I know my dad would have trouble spotting some of the 'hidden' items. If you've got a few hours and a few bucks burning your pocket you could do alot worse then get this game. Play it and you won't be disapointed.

Hi all,  Here we have a very nice game for passing the time. Not very hard but does take time to find hidden items. I do give this a thumbs up for a simple point and click mouse game. I see that there is a Hero of the kingdom 2 out with a new storyline. Will be interesting to see if it can keep up with this nice game.

I found it to be quite a addictive game. You could compare it to a hidden object game but it's a different spin on the genre and it's has some simple RPG elements. The story is pretty standard RPG/Hero tale but it only there to hold the rest together.  It's the gameplay that gets you to keep playing, especially if you like collecting different items and hunting collectibles with some lit item management.

Casual and interesting point and click with a clean interface, decent music, and an ok story. It's about to win awards, but it is a good way to spend $5 and 5 hours. Took me 4.3 hours to get 100% completed - Just doing the story and sidequests was probably 4.25 hours :P

Short but sweet. I enjoyed it from the start to the end, it kept me occupied.  Only thing that could possibly be annoying is you have to look hard to get some of the achievements, and one of the eggs is in a devious spot.
Probably my biggest gaming surprise this whole year so far. It's like playing one of the old Infinity Engine games on speed mode. Surprisingly fun and engaging. Two thumbs up!

Not really an adventure game, it's a hidden object game. There is no real strategy since choice is so limited. It's just doing a ton of busywork that wears out its welcome. It's a good looking game, which is imperative given the hidden objects like mushrooms, eggs, and treasures. So if you want to get all the achievements, it requires scanning a lot of screens. It's rather short, it's cheap, and the story is okay. It's also annoyingly repetitive, constrictive, and requires thousands of clicks and nothing more. 5/10

Surprisingly good!  The story is so clicheed that its not even worth a yawn. The characters are all cardboard images. The primary game-mechanics are hidden objects. Graphics are okay, no voiceovers, no animations, no cutscenes or anything else you would expect from a game released in 2012.  I really dont know why this is good at all, but if you want to sink 4-6 hours into a rather forgettable casual gaming experience you probably cannot do much better than this one, it somehow end up being a lot fun!
Superb addicting game! :D Short but pretty cool. I couldn't stop playing. I played from 01 am to 3 am!  Really cool indie game ;)

Great game for people who want an adventure game with very very limited difficulty.  The game is made to be from a time long ago when we were only young adventurers. The game feels old and I will not give it a great review, but it was fun.  The game play repeats but the story of our youthful adventures is all worth it. On a sale just buy it.  This game gets a 6.5/10.
Nice Game, short (only 3-4 hours). Good price point. A bit like advanture puzzle something.  Recommnded.
Mushroom clicker simulator  10/10 would buy again

As my man AJS would say FOUR HOURs..... I played this game till the end and was thourghly entertained start to finish for the price (I had a discount) i can recomened this to other gamers who are interested in point and click adventure.
great game! it's very simple, but addictive.

Yes this game is overrated. Yes it has linear generic story. Gameplay is easy - you just pointing and clicking and stuff happens, but it has something that dragged me into it. It's just good casual game for a boring evening. That's it.
Good hidden object game with good story.

Absolutely brilliant!! This was a hidden gem for me. I became aware of it through the steam trading card system as I got a voucher to get a percentage off and it was well worth the buy. To be honest I'd buy it at full price, and even though I've completed the game I am driven to acquire all the acheivements which can be done with patience.  It is a point and click game, but does require a sharp eye and problem solving skills. Out of all the point and click games this is the most compelling that I've played, with sound logic, well portrayed graphics and timeless storyline. Must buy for anyone who wants an easy going gaming experience.
10/10 unexpected good, i had a lot of fun
An incredibly fun kingdom management / crafting game. I didn't want it to end. 9/10, wish it was longer and a little deeper, or had some sandbox mode.
i love this game but why steam don't sell Hero of the Kingdom II on greenlight :(
Really enjoyed it. Mellow and simple. In the end it appealed to the completist in me.
Great game for what it is. Easy to complete 100%, very relaxing gameplay, nice graphics and story. Wish it was longer. Perfect casual experience.
Fun game, extremly short for it's price.

I got this game as part of a bundle for $3, but I would happily pay more. It is a great fun little game, with about 2-5 hours play time depending on how OCD you are on collecting all the achievements. There is no time limit on the tasks, and you can play it at your leisure. It is a little bit puzzle, a little bit adventure, and a little bit spot the hidden objects. I really enjoyed this game and I hope they do another one.
Not worth full price just on a content quantity basis, but when on sale, it's absolutely worth it. A simple, but well revieled story with very casual gameplay mechanics. Not meant to be challenging.
complited for 3hours
A short, light, and relaxing adventure.

I don't usually play point & click adventure games, but I find this game pretty interesting. The hidden object/adventure/resource management combo works well.  Story is alright, but mainly the unlockables keep you playing. Soundtrack is okay - relaxing, but no tracks that really stand out.  8/10
A surprisingly fun and good game for what it is.  Thanks for a Linux version!

Great game if you need a break from challenging FPS or grueling strategy. Hero of the Kingdom has a very linear story; You play as the only child of a farmer who goes to town, leaving you to look after the farm. You go about performing various tasks and learning the basics of the game. There is no real challange to the game, you cannot die, but you require sleep in order to perform tasks, and some tasks are more tedious than others.  As you progress you'll discover skills, these skills allow you to find things that are scattered throughout each of the areas. Maxing the skills allows you to complete a moderate amount of the challanges presented and also allow you to complete the game quicker.  This is an easy 100% achievment get. Though it is can take up a lot of time as some of the objects are cleverly hidden.  At the end of the day I would definitly recomend this game to those looking to take a break from the norm, particularly at a sale price.
First 5 minutes had me wondering if this was a game at all. Click this. Now click this. Thankfully the game soon opens up and becomes more sandbox-ey. Nice game to chill out to for 3 hours.

It's a fun little game, with which to while away an afternoon. Not much in the way of replayability once completed, and its very easy to get 100% achievements without even trying.  Not worth 6.99 though. For 0.99 its a wonderful little purchase though.

Hero of the Kingdom is a pretty simple, straightforward time-waster, but it's a fun enough few hours. If you can get it on the cheap, it's not a bad pick. Completing the game is quite simple, but there are a few achievements to grind out if you care to.
Great simple game, it's not hard or complex, but enjoyable. Nice story as well. Well worth a couple of quid
Hero of the Kingdom is a nice and casual point and click adventure. Sort of a 'Where's Wally' style. It is quite short, but it is a nice and relaxing experience.
loved it , but i wudnt mind it having some extra content , like an expansion or smthing

Fun casual game. Nice peaceful atmosphere, you have to look a lot at pixels if you are a completionist like me. You can also optimise your resources, but it's not difficult at all. You just have to click at things to succeed. All in all worth a couple of Euros.
Really addicting for some reason. Real simple.

Very good casual game. It's fairly easy to finish, even with 100% achievements. The game combines point-and-click adventure with Where's Waldo to create an easy going experience, where you can spend as much time as you want to finish the quest. There is a downside: once you've found everything there is to find (resulting in 100% achievement) the game is completely over and doesn't renew any of the fishing, hunting or shrooming quests. All in all a good, relatively short game to buy in a sale.
Simple but addicting game . I really enjoyed it , a bit short to be honest .  9/10

Great game if you're looking for about 5 hours of fun. I was looking for a game to 100% fast and this game deffinetly delivered. (You can basicly just chill and listen to music while playing, so it makes it easy to grind out acheivments)
This game is cheap price and very easy  but it's a good game with the hidden item ,the game system ,The difficulty increases slowly. Overall, it's okay :)
Finished in one sitting because I couldn't stop playing.

I have owned this game for awhile but the other day I decided to start playing it out of boredom. I can honestly say this scratched the itch that I was feeling.   It feels like a cross between a point and click adventure with some RPG-like elements and one of those hidden object games thrown in for fun. It's not overly complicated but has a lot to collect and do in a short amount of time. I managed to complete the game, and all 38 Steam achievements in about 4 hours.   A good tip: When you start hunting bears you need poison. The first way to get it is to buy it from a shady guy, but don't buy it from him. Instead advance the story a little further till you unlock someone who will craft it for you for free.
A really nice drawn clicker, with a naïve plot but still cute and adorable. One more reason to recommend - a rather easy-to-perfect game

A nice break from all the labor and inventory management of a standard RPG. The game makes great use of the maps by adding new items to click on as your character learns to utilize them. There are always new quests to do or activities to complete. Well worth the price during a sale.  Only issue I've had is some sound effects don't always complete so my speakers continuously play white noise until I exit the game (roughly every 20 minutes).

Actually played Hero of the Kingdom II first which I loved so I bought this first game after.  Just as easy and fun as the second, I noticed money was easier to get in this( or maybe I got used to it after the second one). A straightforward point and click adventure along with little hidden objects achievements going on. Don't expect a huge story, it's textbook story tale hero.  Extremely nice little game for a few hours.

Took me under 4 hours to get to 100% achievements. Was totally worth of the money and overall it was really simple and good game.  It was fun to earn money by 'doing work'. Meaning that you can either trade or go fish / collect flowers etc.

Not a single bad thing to say. Casual gaming at it's best, If you like adventure, beautiful graphics, a good mix of chance, luck, fortune, wit and intuitive skill, then just throw in an incredible story line, which is chock full of irony and will leave you wanting to play the sequel. 2 thumbs up, 5 stars, whatever.....
It's not a bad game. TBH not what I was expecting but not disappointed with it. I'd say give it a shot nothing to lose when its on sale for $0.49.
